SEARCH
Module io.github.ascopes.jct
Package io.github.ascopes.jct.pathwrappers

Class RamDirectory

java.lang.Object
io.github.ascopes.jct.pathwrappers.AbstractTestDirectory<RamDirectory>
io.github.ascopes.jct.pathwrappers.RamDirectory
All Implemented Interfaces:
PathWrapper
@API(since="0.0.1", status=EXPERIMENTAL) public final class RamDirectory extends AbstractTestDirectory<RamDirectory>
A wrapper around a temporary in-memory file system that exposes the root path of said file system.

This provides a utility for constructing complex and dynamic directory tree structures quickly and simply using fluent chained methods.

These file systems are integrated into the FileSystem API, and can be configured to automatically destroy themselves once this RamPath handle is garbage collected.

In addition, these paths follow POSIX file system semantics, meaning that files are handled with case-sensitive names, and use forward slashes to separate paths.

While this will create a global FileSystem, it is recommended that you only interact with the file system via this class to prevent potentially confusing behaviour elsewhere.

Since:
0.0.1
Author:
Ashley Scopes

  • Method Details

    • newRamDirectory

      @CheckReturnValue public static RamDirectory newRamDirectory(String name)
      Create a new in-memory path.

      The underlying in-memory file system will be closed and destroyed when the returned object is garbage collected, or when AbstractTestDirectory.close() is called on it manually.

      Parameters:
      name - a symbolic name to give the path. This must be a valid POSIX directory name.
      Returns:
      the in-memory path.
      See Also:
      • newRamDirectory(String, boolean)

    • newRamDirectory

      @CheckReturnValue public static RamDirectory newRamDirectory(String name, boolean closeOnGc)
      Create a new in-memory path.
      Parameters:
      name - a symbolic name to give the path. This must be a valid POSIX directory name.
      closeOnGc - if true, then the AbstractTestDirectory.close() operation will be called on the underlying FileSystem as soon as the returned object from this method is garbage collected. If false, then you must close the underlying file system manually using the AbstractTestDirectory.close() method on the returned object. Failing to do so will lead to resources being leaked.
      Returns:
      the in-memory path.
      See Also:
      • newRamDirectory(String)
